questions.explanation:
Solution:

Upper trunk involvement Lower trunk involvement is seen in Klumpke’s paralysis. Klumpke’s paralysis occurs due to forcible hyperabduction of the upper arm (e.g. falling person catches a tree) leading to lower trunk (T1 > C8) brachial plexus injury. It causes ipsilateral claw hand & horner’s syndrome.

Highyeild:

Klumpke's paralysis Klumpke's paralysis occurs due to injury to lower trunk (mainly T1 & partly C8) of brachial plexus T1 provides the segmental supply to the intrinsic muscles of the hand. So due to its paralysis the hand assumes a clawed appearance reflecting the unopposed action of the long flexors and extensors of the fingers. There is slowly progressive weakness which usually starts in the small muscles of the hand (T1)and spreads to involve the finger flexors (C8). There is sensory loss on the medial aspect of the forearm (T1) extending into the medial side of the hand and to the little finger (C8). There is a slow insidious onset of wasting of the small muscles of the hand, which often starts on the lateral side with involvement of the thenar eminence and first dorsal interosseous. There is pain and paraesthesia in the medial aspect of the forearm extending to the little finger, and this is often aggravated by carrying weight. There is often an associated horner's syndrome (ptosis and constriction of the pupil) which occurs as a result of pull or traction of the cervical sympathetic chain.

questions.correct_answer: B. Extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees is impossible
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees is impossible Axillary nerve supplies deltoid ms. Which is responsible for shoulder abduction of 15-90; so injury to the axillary nerve could not affect overhead abduction.

Highyeild:

AXILLARY NERVE Anatomy: The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and curves backwards on the lower border of the subscapularis. It crosses the quadrangular space and comes to lie on the medial side of the surgical neck of the humerus, medial and inferior to the capsule of the shoulder joint. Here it divides into anterior and posterior branches. The posterior branch supplies the teres minor and posterior part of the deltoid and terminates as the cutaneous nerve which supplies the skin over the lower-half of the deltoid. The anterior branch continues horizontally between the deltoid and the surgical neck of the humerus, and supplies the rest of the deltoid.

questions.text: ‘Ulnar paradox’ is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High ulnar lesion High ulnar lesion causes less clawing compared to low ulnar lesion, this is called Ulnar paradox.

Highyeild:

Ulnar paradox:- Ulnar nerve injury at the wrist causes 'more' clawing (severe interphalangeal flexion deformity, due to unopposed flexor digitorum profundus). Ulnar nerve injury at the elbow paralyzes flexor digitorum profundus and leads to 'less' clawing (less interphalangeal flexion deformity). This is known as the ‘ulnar paradox‘ – you would expect a more pronounced deformity, due to ulnar nerve injury at the elbow (as compared with wrist level) but in fact, the opposite occurs.
